Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Sanguineous vs. Crystalloid CPB Prime in Pediatric Cardiac Surgery

Participants.evidence: Forty pediatric patients were enrolled at IWK Health Centre, Halifax, Canada, between August 2020 and June 2021. Eligibility criteria included weight <30 kg and exclusion of severe hematologic or multi-organ conditions.

Objective.evidence: To identify specific inflammatory mediators in sanguineous CPB prime and their impact on the inflammatory response at CPB initiation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcome was the concentration of inflammatory mediators at CPB initiation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation: Not applicable as this was a post-hoc analysis of a prospective cohort study.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty pediatric patients were enrolled at IWK Health Centre, Halifax, Canada, between August 2020 and June 2021.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Sanguineous prime contained supraphysiologic concentrations of complement mediators C2, C3, C3a, C3b, and C5a. Upon CPB initiation, patients receiving sanguineous prime exhibited significantly higher levels of C2, C3, C3b, C5, and C5a (p<0.001) compared to the crystalloid group.
